  <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="margin-left:.5in;text-align:center;

  <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="margin-left:.5in;text-align:right;

  53</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:avoid">
  <u><font size="2">PART I</font></u></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 1.</font></u></b><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </font>
  <b><u><font size="2">Description of Business</font></u></b></p>
  <h5 style="margin-left:.5in">General</h5>
  <p class="MsoBodyText" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:
avoid"><font size="2">The Company is a processor, manufacturer and distributor of a broad array
  of high value-added, high margin products and services.&nbsp; The Company utilizes
  any one or a combination of several different processes at each of its
  operating facilities to add substantial margin and value to raw materials
  acquired from primary steel and other metal producers.&nbsp; Underlying each of
  these processes and services is a common set of core competencies in steel and
  metal processing.&nbsp; These core competencies are the foundation upon which all
  the Company's operations and products and services are based.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company is organized into three reportable
  segments -Processed Steel Products, Building Products and Heat Treating.&nbsp; The
  Processed Steel Products segment produces a wide variety of cold-rolled strip
  steel products, coated sheet steel products and strapping products in 16
  facilities in 7 states and Mexico.&nbsp; The Company's processed cold-rolled strip
  steel products comprise a part of the cold-rolled sheet steel market that is
  defined by more precise widths, improved surface conditions, more diverse
  chemistry and tighter gauge tolerances than are supplied by primary
  manufacturers of flat-rolled steel products.&nbsp; The Company's cold-rolled strip
  steel products are sold primarily to manufacturers in the automotive,
  automotive supply, power and hand tools and hardware industries, as well as to
  other customers who demand critical specifications in their raw material
  needs.&nbsp; The Company's coated steel products, which include galvanized,
  galvalume and pre-painted sheet products, are sold primarily to the commercial
  and residential metal building industry for roofing and siding applications.&nbsp;
  The Company's heavy duty steel strapping products are used to close and
  reinforce packages such as cartons and crates for shipping.&nbsp; The Company also
  operates two material management facilities that link primary steel producers
  to end-user manufacturers.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Building Products segment, comprised of 36
  facilities in 21 states, primarily includes the processing of sheet steel to
  produce a wide variety of building and construction products.&nbsp; Many of the
  Company's building products meet and exceed increasingly stringent building
  codes and insurance company requirements governing both residential and
  commercial construction.&nbsp; This segment's products are sold to major retail
  home centers, lumber and building material wholesalers, buying groups,
  discount stores, distributors, and general contractors engaged in residential,
  industrial and commercial construction.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Heat Treating segment operates 16
  facilities in 10 states and Canada and provides a wide array of processes
  which refine the metallurgical properties of customer-owned metal products for
  a variety of consumer and industrial applications where critical performance
  characteristics are required.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Note 15 of the Company's consolidated financial
  statements included in Item 8 herein provides information related to the
  Company's business segments in accordance with accounting principles generally
  accepted in the United States of America.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b>
  <font size="2">Recent Developments </font> </b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">In April 2003, the Company acquired
  Construction Metals, Inc. (Construction Metals), an Ontario, California-based
  manufacturer with locations in Fontana, California;
  Las Vegas, Nevada;
  Phoenix, Arizona;
  Hayward, California;
  Denver, Colorado;
  Kent, Washington;
  Escondido, California;
  Salt Lake City, Utah; and
  Albuquerque, New Mexico.&nbsp; Construction
  Metals manufactures and distributes a wide array of building products which
  are sold to retail and wholesale customers throughout the western United
  States.&nbsp; Note 2 of the Company's consolidated financial statements included in
  Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding the Company's
  acquisition of Construction Metals.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">In May 2003, the Company acquired Air Vent Inc.
  (Air Vent), which operates manufacturing facilities in Dallas, Texas;
  Clinton, Iowa; and Lincolnton, North Carolina and operates a
  sales office and customer service department in Peoria, Illinois.&nbsp; Air Vent
  manufactures and distributes a complete line of ventilation products and
  related accessories.&nbsp; Note 2 of the Company's consolidated financial
  statements included in Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding
  the Company's acquisition of Air Vent.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">In December 2003, the Company entered into a
  joint venture with Duferco Farrell Corporation in which the Company acquired a
  50% partnership interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC.&nbsp; The joint venture
  manufactures and distributes cold-rolled strip steel products at its facility
  in Farrell, Pennsylvania.&nbsp; Note 6
  of the Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein
  provides additional information regarding the Company's 50% interest in the
  joint venture.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">In December 2003, the Company completed an
  offering of 3,000,000 shares of common stock at a price of $24.75 per share.&nbsp;
  Net proceeds to the Company from the common stock offering approximated $70
  million, and were used to pay down existing debt. &nbsp;Note 11 of the Company's
  consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides
  additional information regarding the Company's common stock offering.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">In
  connection with the Company's common stock offering, the Company granted the
  underwriters an option to purchase additional shares of common stock to cover
  over-allotments.&nbsp; In January 2004, the underwriters exercised a portion of
  this option and purchased an additional 214,625 shares of the Company's common
  stock at a price of $24.75 per share.&nbsp; Net proceeds to the Company associated
  with the purchase of these additional shares aggregated approximately $5
  million. Note 18 of the Company's consolidated
  financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides additional information
  regarding the Company's common stock offering.</font></p>
  <h5 style="margin-left:.5in">Industry Overview</h5>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Steel and metal processors occupy a market
  niche that exists between the primary steel and metal producers and end-users
  and others.&nbsp; Primary steel and metal producers typically focus on the sale of
  standard size and tolerance steel and other metals to large volume purchasers,
  including steel and metal processors.&nbsp; At the same time, end-users require
  steel with closer tolerances and with shorter lead times than the primary
  steel and metal producers can provide efficiently.&nbsp; Steel processors, through
  the application of various higher value-added processes such as cold-rolling
  and specialized heat-treating methods, process steel of a precise grade,
  temper, tolerance and finish.&nbsp; End product manufacturers incorporate the
  processed steel into finished goods.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b>
  <font size="2">Products and Services</font></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><i>
  <font size="2">Processed Steel Products Segment<br>
  </font></i></b><font size="2"><i>
  Cold-Rolled Strip Steel</i>.&nbsp;
  The Company's cold-rolled strip steel is used in applications which demand
  more precise widths, improved surface conditions and tighter gauge tolerances
  than are supplied by primary producers of flat-rolled steel products.&nbsp;
  Consistent with its strategy of focusing on high value-added products and
  services, the Company produces a broad range of fully processed cold-rolled
  strip steel products.&nbsp; The Company buys wide, open tolerance sheet steel in
  coils from primary producers and processes it to specific customer orders by
  performing such computer-aided processes as cold reduction, annealing, edge
  rolling and slitting.&nbsp; Cold reduction is the rolling of steel to a specified
  thickness, tolerance and finish.&nbsp; Annealing is a thermal process which changes
  hardness and certain metallurgical characteristics of steel.&nbsp; Edge rolling
  involves conditioning edges of processed steel into square, full round or
  partially round shapes.&nbsp; Slitting is the cutting of steel to specified
  widths.&nbsp; Depending on customer specifications, one or more of these processes
  are utilized to produce steel strip of a precise grade, temper, tolerance and
  finish.&nbsp; Customers for the Company's strip steel products include
  manufacturers in the automotive, automotive supply, power and hand tool,
  hardware and other industries.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company operates nine rolling mills at its
  facilities in Cleveland, Ohio and Buffalo, New York, all of which are
  QS-9000 registered.&nbsp; Equipment at these facilities includes a computerized,
  three-stand, four-high tandem mill and eight single-stand, two-and four-high
  mills.&nbsp; The Company has the capability to process coils up to a maximum of 72
  inch outside diameter and roll widths of up to 50 inches.&nbsp; Its rolling mills
  include automatic gauge control systems with hydraulic screw downs allowing
  for microsecond adjustments during processing.&nbsp; The Company's computerized
  mills enable it to satisfy an industry demand for a wide range of steel from
  heavier gauge and special alloy steels to low carbon and light gauge steels,
  in each case having a high-quality finish and precision gauge tolerance.&nbsp; This
  equipment can process flat-rolled steel to specific customer requirements for
  thickness tolerances as close as .00025 inches.&nbsp; The Company also operates a
  56-inch reversing mill which it believes is one of the widest of its type in
  the specialty strip steel industry.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's rolling facilities are further complemented by 17 high
  convection annealing furnaces, which allow for shorter annealing times than
  conventional annealers.&nbsp; Fourteen of the Company's furnaces and bases employ
  state-of-the-art technology, incorporating the use of a hydrogen atmosphere
  for the production of cleaner and more uniform steel.&nbsp; As a result of the
  Company's annealing capabilities, it is able to produce cold-rolled strip
  steel with improved consistency in terms of thickness, hardness, molecular
  grain structure and surface.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company can produce certain strip steel
  products on oscillated coils, which wind strip steel similar to the way
  fishing line is wound on a reel.&nbsp; Oscillating the strip steel enables the
  Company to put at least six times greater volume of finished product on a coil
  than standard ribbon winding, allowing customers to achieve longer production
  runs by reducing the number of equipment shut-downs to change coils.&nbsp;
  Customers are thus able to increase productivity, reduce downtime, improve
  yield and lengthen die life.&nbsp; These benefits to customers allow the Company to
  achieve higher margins on oscillate products.&nbsp; To the Company's knowledge,
  only a few other steel producers are able to produce oscillated coils, and the
  Company is not aware of any competitor that can produce 12,000 pound oscillate
  coils, the maximum size the Company produces.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Cold-Rolled Strip Steel Joint Venture.</font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;
  The Company has a 50% interest in a joint venture that has one facility in
  Pennsylvania where it manufacturers and distributes cold-rolled strip steel
  products.&nbsp; Note 6 of the Company's consolidated financial statements included
  in Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding the Company's 50%
  interest in the joint venture.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Steel Strapping Products.</font></i><font size="2">&nbsp;
  Steel strapping is a binding and packaging material used to close and
  reinforce shipping units such as bales, boxes, cartons, coils, crates and
  skids.&nbsp; The Company is one of only four domestic manufacturers of high-tensile
  steel strapping, which is subject to strength requirements imposed by the
  American Society for Testing Materials for packaging of different products for
  common carrier transport.&nbsp; This high-tensile steel strapping is essential to
  producers of large, heavy products such as steel, paper and lumber where
  reliability of the packaging material is critical to the safe transport of the
  product.&nbsp; The Company's steel strapping facility is QS-9000 and ISO-14001
  registered and is located in Buffalo, New York.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Coated Steel Products<b>.&nbsp; </b></font></i>
  <font size="2">The Company's coated steel products are used
  primarily in the building products and construction markets and include,&nbsp;
  galvanized and galvalume, pre-painted cold rolled, galvanized &amp; galvalume,
  acrylic coated galvanized &amp; galvalume and PVC coatings for spiral pipe.&nbsp;
  Materials are available in an unlimited number of colors and coating
  qualities.&nbsp; The Company's&nbsp; cold rolled low carbon drawing steels and high
  strength low alloy steels are used primarily in the automotive market and are
  supplied to second and third tier automotive-stamping manufacturers.&nbsp; In
  addition, one of the Company's two locations which produces coated&nbsp; steel
  products is ISO-900l registered.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Materials Management.<b>&nbsp; </b></font></i>
  <font size="2">The Company also operates two state-of-the-art
  materials management facilities in New York and Michigan that link primary
  steel producers and end-user manufacturers by integrating the inventory
  purchasing, receiving, inspection, billing, storage and shipping functions and
  producing true just-in-time delivery of materials.&nbsp; The Company's facilities
  receive shipments of steel by rail and truck from primary steel producers,
  which retain ownership of the steel until it is delivered to the end-user
  manufacturer.&nbsp; The Company inspects the steel and stores it in a
  climate-controlled environment on a specialized stacker crane and rack
  system.&nbsp; When an order is placed, the Company can deliver the steel to the
  end-user manufacturer within one hour using trucks that have been custom
  designed for facilitating the loading and unloading process.&nbsp; This enables
  end-user manufacturers to reduce their raw material inventory.&nbsp; These
  facilities are ISO-9001 registered and have certain proprietary data
  processing systems that link the primary steel producer with the end-user
  manufacturer and also link both parties to the facilities.&nbsp; </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Steel Pickling Joint Venture.<b>&nbsp; </b>
  </font>
  </i><font size="2">The Company has a 31% interest in a joint
  venture that has two steel pickling operations in Ohio.&nbsp; After the hot-rolling
  process, the surface of sheet steel is left with a residue known as scale,
  which must be removed prior to further processing by a cleaning process known
  as pickling.&nbsp; This joint venture pickles steel on a toll basis, receiving fees
  for pickling services without acquiring ownership of the steel.&nbsp; Note 6 of the
  Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides
  additional information regarding the Company's 31% interest in the joint
  venture.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><i>
  <font size="2">Building Products Segment<br>
  </font></i></b><font size="2">The Building Products segment is the result of
  the acquisition of nine synergistic businesses over the last seven years that
  are primarily, but not exclusively, manufacturers of metal products used in
  the residential and light commercial building market.&nbsp; As a result, the
  Company operates 36 facilities throughout the United States giving it a
  national base of operations to provide customer support, delivery, service and
  quality to a number of regional and nationally based customers, as well as
  providing the Company with manufacturing and distribution efficiencies.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company manufactures more than 5,000
  products sold to lumber and building material wholesalers, buying groups,
  discount and major retail home centers, HVAC/roofing distributors and
  residential, industrial and commercial contractors.&nbsp; The Company's product
  offerings includes a full line of ventilation products and accessories;
  mailboxes; roof edging, underlayment and flashing; soffit; drywall corner
  bead; structural support products; coated coil stock; metal roofing and
  accessories; steel framing; rain-carrying systems, including gutters and
  accessories; bath cabinets; access doors; roof hatches and smoke vents;
  builders' hardware, shelving and closet rods; grilles and registers;
  diffusers; and fasteners, each of which can be sold separately or as an
  integral part of a package or program sale.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Many of the Company's products are used to
  integrate the architectural design and building process, improve the life
  expectancy and functionality of a structure or its components, including
  situations of severe weather or seismic activity, and facilitate compliance
  with increasingly stringent building codes and insurance company
  requirements.&nbsp; </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's building products are
  manufactured primarily from galvanized, galvalume and painted steel, anodized
  and painted aluminum, copper, brass, zinc and various plastic compounds.&nbsp;
  These additional metal purchases, when added to the Company's existing
  Processed Steel Products segment purchases, enhances the Company's purchasing
  position due to the increased total volume and value added component of these
  purchases.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's production capabilities allows it
  to process the wide range of metals and plastics necessary for manufacturing
  building products.&nbsp; The Company's equipment includes automatic roll forming
  machines, stamping presses, shears, press brakes, paint lines, milling,
  welding, injection molding and numerous automated assembly machines.&nbsp; All
  equipment is maintained through a constant preventative maintenance program,
  including in-house tool and die shops, allowing the Company to meet the
  demanding service requirements of many of its customers.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Building Products segment has operating
  facilities located in Arizona, California, Colorado,
  Florida, Georgia,
  Illinois, Iowa,
  Michigan, Minnesota,
  Mississippi, Nebraska,
  Nevada, New Mexico,
  New Jersey, North Carolina,
  Ohio, Tennessee,
  Texas, Utah,
  Washington and Wisconsin.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">In January 2004, the Company increased its
  presence in the building products market through the acquisition of Renown
  Specialties Company Ltd. (Renown).&nbsp; Renown is located in Thornhill, Ontario
  and is a designer, manufacturer and distributor of structural connectors.&nbsp;
  Note 18 of the Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8
  herein provides additional information regarding the Company's acquisition of
  Renown.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><i>
  <font size="2">Heat-Treating Segment<br>
  </font></i></b><font size="2">The Company's Heat Treating Segment provides a
  wide range of metallurgical heat-treating processes in which customer-owned
  metal parts are exposed to precise temperatures, atmospheres and quenchants
  and other conditions to improve their mechanical properties, durability and
  wear resistance.&nbsp; These processes include case-hardening, neutral-hardening
  and through-hardening, annealing, normalizing, vacuum hardening, carburizing,
  nitriding and brazing, as well as a host of other processes.&nbsp; These
  heat-treating processes can harden, soften or otherwise impart desired
  properties to parts made of steel, aluminum, copper, powdered metals and
  various alloys and other metals.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company operates 16 heat-treating
  facilities in Alabama, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana,
  Michigan, North Carolina,
  Ohio, Pennsylvania,
  South Carolina, Tennessee and Kitchener, Ontario.&nbsp; The Company maintains
  a metallurgical laboratory at each facility with trained metallurgists
  providing a range of testing capabilities to add value to treated parts and
  enhance quality control.&nbsp; Consistent quality control is maintained by
  application of a statistical process control system and QS-9000 or ISO-9001
  registration.&nbsp; In addition, 3 of the Company's heat treating facilities are
  ISO-14001 registered.&nbsp; The Company also maintains a fleet of trucks and
  trailers to provide rapid turnaround time for its customers.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Due to time and costs associated with
  transporting materials and customers' need for just-in-time delivery of heat
  treated products, the commercial heat treating industry has developed as a
  regional industry concentrated in major industrial areas of the country.&nbsp; In
  addition, the commercial heat treating industry has realized significant
  growth in recent years as many companies involved in the manufacture of metal
  components outsource their heat treating requirements.&nbsp; </font> </p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Quality Assurance</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company places great importance on
  providing its customers with high-quality products for use in critical
  applications.&nbsp; The Company carefully selects its raw material vendors and uses
  computerized inspection and analysis to ensure that the materials entering its
  production processes will be able to meet the most critical customer
  specifications.&nbsp; To ensure these specifications are met, the Company uses
  documented procedures utilizing statistical process control systems linked
  directly to processing equipment to monitor all stages of production.&nbsp;
  Physical, chemical and metallographic analyses are performed during the
  production process to verify that mechanical and dimensional properties,
  cleanliness, surface characteristics and chemical content are within
  specification.&nbsp; In addition, all of the Company's facilities that provide
  services or products to the automotive industry, including 13 of the Company's
  heat-treating facilities, are QS-9000 registered.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Suppliers and Raw Materials</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Steel and metal processing companies are
  required to maintain substantial inventories of raw material in order to
  accommodate the short lead times and just-in-time delivery requirements of
  their customers.&nbsp; Accordingly, the Company generally maintains its inventory
  of raw materials at levels that it believes are sufficient to satisfy the
  anticipated needs of its &nbsp;customers based upon historic buying practices and
  market conditions.&nbsp; The primary raw material processed by the Company is
  flat-rolled steel, purchased at regular intervals on an as-needed basis
  primarily from approximately 37 major North American suppliers, as well as a
  limited number of foreign steel suppliers. .&nbsp; The Company has no long-term
  commitments with any of its suppliers.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Technical Services</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company employs a staff of engineers,
  metallurgists, and other technical personnel and maintains fully-equipped,
  modern laboratories to support its operations.&nbsp; These laboratories enable the
  Company to verify, analyze and document the physical, chemical, metallurgical
  and mechanical properties of its raw materials and products.&nbsp; In addition, the
  Company's engineering staff also employs a range of CAD/CAM programs to design
  highly specialized and technically precise products.&nbsp; Technical service
  personnel also work in conjunction with the Company's sales force to determine
  the types of products and services required for the particular needs of the
  Company's customers.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Sales and Marketing</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's products and services are sold
  primarily by Company sales personnel and outside sales representatives located
  throughout the United States, Canada and Mexico. </font> </p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Customers and Distribution</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company has approximately 10,000 customers
  located throughout the United States, Canada and Mexico
  principally in the automotive, automotive supply, building and construction,
  steel, machinery and fastener industries.&nbsp; Major customers include automobile
  manufacturers and suppliers, building product distributors, and commercial and
  residential contractors.&nbsp; During 2003, one customer of the Company (The Home
  Depot), accounted for 10.7% of the Company's consolidated net sales.&nbsp; No other
  customer represented 10% or more of the Company's consolidated net sales for
  2003.&nbsp; &nbsp;No one customer of the Company represented 10% or more of the
  Company's consolidated net sales for 2001 and 2002.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">During 2001 and 2002, one customer (General
  Motors) of the Company's Processed Steel Products segment accounted for 10.2%
  and 10.4%, respectively, of this segment's net sales.&nbsp; No one customer of the
  Company's Processed Steel Products segment represented 10% or more of this
  segment's net sales for 2003.&nbsp; During 2001, 2002 and 2003, one customer (The
  Home Depot) of the Company's Building Products segment accounted for 17.2%,
  18.5% and 20.3%, respectively, of this segment's net sales.&nbsp; During 2001, one
  customer (General Motors) of the Company's Heat Treating segment accounted for
  10.6% of this segment's net sales. &nbsp;No one customer of the Company's Heat
  Treating segment represented 10% or more of this segment's net sales for 2002
  and 2003.&nbsp; No one other single customer accounted for more than 10% of any
  segment's net sales during this three year period.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's Processed Steel Products segment
  manufactures products to customer order as opposed to inventory.&nbsp; The Building
  Products segment manufactures products to both customer order and inventory.&nbsp;
  The Heat Treating segment processes customer owned metal parts to various
  metallurgical heat treating specifications.&nbsp; Although the Company negotiates
  annual sales orders with the majority of its customers, these orders are
  subject to customer confirmation as to product amounts and delivery dates.&nbsp;
  </font>
  </p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Competition</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The steel processing market is highly
  competitive.&nbsp; The Company competes with a small number of other steel
  processors, some of which also focus on fully processed, high value-added
  steel products.&nbsp; The Company competes on the basis of precision and range of
  achievable tolerances, quality, price and the ability to meet delivery
  schedules dictated by customers.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company competes with numerous suppliers of
  building products in its market based on the broad range of products offered,
  quality, price and delivery.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company competes with a small number of
  suppliers of heat treating services in its market areas on the basis of
  processes offered, quality, price and delivery.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Employees</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">At December 31, 2003, the Company
  employed approximately 3,800 people, of which 632, or approximately 17%, are
  represented by collective bargaining agreements.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Seasonality</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 0.5in"><font size="2">The Company's
  revenues are generally lower in the first and fourth quarters primarily due to
  customer plant shutdowns in the automotive industry due to holidays and model
  changeovers, as well as reduced activity in the building and construction
  industry due to inclement weather.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: 0.5in"><b><font size="2">Backlog</font></b></p>
  <font size="2">
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Because of the nature of the Company's products
  and the short lead time order cycle, backlog is not a significant factor in
  the Company's business.&nbsp; The Company believes that substantially all of its
  firm orders existing on December 31, 2003 will be shipped prior to the end of
  2004.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Governmental Regulation</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's processing centers and
  manufacturing facilities are subject to many federal, state and local
  requirements relating to the protection of the environment.&nbsp; The Company
  believes that it operates its business in material compliance with all
  environmental laws and regulations, does not anticipate any material
  expenditures in order to meet environmental requirements and does not believe
  that future compliance with such laws and regulations will have a material
  adverse effect on its financial condition or results of operations.&nbsp; However,
  the Company could incur operating costs or capital expenditures in complying
  with more stringent environmental requirements in the future or with current
  requirements if they are applied to the Company's facilities in a way the
  Company does not anticipate.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company's operations are also governed by
  many other laws and regulations.&nbsp; The Company believes that it is in material
  compliance with these laws and regulations and does not believe that future
  compliance with such laws and regulations will have a material adverse effect
  on its financial condition or results of operations.</font></p>
  <h6 style="line-height:normal; margin-left:0.5in"><font size="2">Internet Information</font></h6>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Copies of the Company's Annual Report on Form
  10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q, Current Reports on Form 8-K, and
  amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section 13(a) or
  15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 are available free of charge
  through the Company's Web site (www.gibraltar1.com) as soon as reasonably
  practicable after the Company electronically files the material with, or
  furnishes it to, the Securities and Exchange Commission.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 2.</font></u><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </font>
  <u><font size="2">Description of Properties</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company
  maintains its corporate headquarters in Buffalo, New York and conducts
  business operations in facilities located throughout the United States.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company
  believes that its primary existing facilities, listed below, and their
  equipment are effectively utilized, well maintained, in good condition and
  will be able to accommodate its capacity needs through 2004.</font></p>

      <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after:avoid">
      <font size="2">Heat treating</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="padding-left:0; padding-right:0; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in; margin-left:0; margin-right:0" height="19">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
  avoid">&nbsp; <font size="2">47,868</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width:67;padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in" height="19">
      <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after:avoid">
      &nbsp;</td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">*&nbsp; Leased.&nbsp; All
  other facilities owned.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 3.</font></u><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </font>
  <u><font size="2">Legal Proceedings</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b>
  <font size="2">&nbsp;</font></b><font size="2">From time to time, the Company is named a
  defendant in legal actions arising out of the normal course of business.&nbsp; The
  Company is not a party to any pending legal proceeding the resolution of which
  the management of the Company believes will have a material adverse effect on
  the Company's results of operations or financial condition or to any other
  pending legal proceedings other than ordinary, routine litigation incidental
  to its business.&nbsp; The Company maintains liability insurance against risks
  arising out of the normal course of business.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 4.</font></u><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </font>
  <u><font size="2">Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">No matters were submitted to a vote of
  security holders during the fourth quarter of the year ended December 31,
  2003.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="margin-left:.5in;text-align:center;
page-break-after:avoid"><b><u><font size="2">PART II</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 5.</font></u><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </font>
  <u><font size="2">Market for Common Equity and Related Stockholder Matters</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">As of December 31,
  2003, there were 120 shareholders of record of the Company's common stock.&nbsp;
  However, the Company believes that it has a significantly higher number of
  shareholders because of the number of shares that are held by nominees.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company's
  common stock is traded in the over-the-counter market and quoted on the
  National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation System -
  National Market System (&quot;NASDAQ&quot;) under the symbol &quot;ROCK.&quot;&nbsp; The following
  table sets forth the high and low sale prices per share for the Company's
  common stock for each quarter of 2003 and 2002 as reported on the NASDAQ
  National Market:</font></p>

  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Company declared dividends of $.040 per
  share in the first quarter of 2003 and $.045 in each of the second and third
  quarters of 2003.&nbsp; As of the date of the Form 10-K filing, no dividend has
  been declared for the fourth quarter of 2003; however, the Company has no
  knowledge of anything that would prevent the Board of Directors from declaring
  a fourth quarter dividend.&nbsp; The Company declared dividends of $.035 per share
  in the first quarter of 2002 and $.040 per share in each of the second, third
  and fourth quarters of 2002.&nbsp; </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Cash dividends are declared at the discretion
  of the Company's Board of Directors.&nbsp; The Board of Directors reviews the
  dividend quarterly and establishes the dividend rate based upon such factors
  as the Company's earnings, financial condition, capital requirements, debt
  covenant requirements and/or other relevant conditions.&nbsp; Although the Company
  expects to continue to declare and pay cash dividends on its common stock in
  the future if earnings are available, the Company cannot assure that either
  cash or stock dividends will be paid in the future or that, if paid, the
  dividends will be paid in the same amount or at the same frequency as paid in
  the past.</font></p>

  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  <b><font size="2">(1)&nbsp;&nbsp; </font>
  </b><font size="2">Consists of the Company's
  non-qualified stock option plan and 1993 incentive stock option plan (which
  expired in 2003). Note 13 of the Company's consolidated financial statements
  included in Item 8 herein provides additional information regarding the
  Company's stock option plans.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
  <b><font size="2">(2)&nbsp;&nbsp; </font>
  </b><font size="2">Consists of the Company's
  2003 incentive stock option plan. Under this plan, 1,500,000 shares of common
  stock are reserved for the future granting of stock options. No options under
  this plan were issued as of December 31, 2003. Note 13 of the Company's
  consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 herein provides
  additional information regarding the Company's stock option plans.</font></p>
      <p class="MsoNormal" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><b><u>

      <td valign="top" style="width:52;padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align:right;line-height:14.0pt;
  page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">2,839</font></td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 7.</font></u><font size="2">&nbsp; <u>
  Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition&nbsp; </u></font>
  <u><font size="2">and Results&nbsp; of
  OpFerations</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b>
  <font size="2">&nbsp;</font></b><font size="2">The following Management's Discussion and
  Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations should be read in
  conjunction with the Company's consolidated financial statements and notes
  thereto included in Item 8 of this Form 10-K.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in"><b>
  <font size="2">Overview</font></b><font size="2"> </font>
  </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in">
  <font size="2">The consolidated financial statements present the financial condition of the
  Company as of December 31, 2003 and 2002, and the consolidated results of
  operations and cash flows of the Company for the years ended December 31,
  2003, 2002 and 2001.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company is organized into three reportable segments -Processed Steel
  Products, Building Products and Heat Treating.&nbsp;
  The Company also held equity positions in two
  joint ventures as of December 31, 2003.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in">
  <font size="2">The Processed Steel Products segment produces a wide variety of cold-rolled
  strip steel products, coated sheet steel products and strapping products.&nbsp;
  This segment primarily serves the automotive industry's leaders, such as
  General Motors, Ford, Chrysler, and Honda. This segment also serves the
  &nbsp;automotive supply and commercial and
  residential metal building industry, as
  well as the power and hand tool and hardware industries. &nbsp;During 2003, the
  Company strengthened its Processed Steel Products segment through its joint
  venture with Duferco Farrell Corporation, in which the Company acquired a 50%
  partnership interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC. The automotive market
  is a very important part of the Company's Processed Steel segment. In 2004,
  the Company plans to continue its longstanding relationships with the domestic
  automotive manufacturers, as well as enhance its present relationships with
  the transplant automobile manufacturers and their suppliers. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Building Products segment processes sheet
  steel to produce a wide variety of building and construction products. This
  segment's products are sold to major retail home centers, such as The Home
  Depot, Lowe's, Menards and Wal-Mart. During 2003, the Company eliminated
  competitors and strengthened its position in the Building Products market
  through the acquisitions of Construction Metals (acquired April 1, 2003) and
  Air Vent (acquired May 1, 2003). These strategic acquisitions enabled the
  Company to broaden its geographic markets, solidify product offerings and
  added approximately $82.4 million to the Company's consolidated net sales for
  2003. In addition, in January 2004, the Company acquired Renown Specialties
  Company Ltd., which is a manufacturer and distributor of construction hardware
  products in Canada. The acquisition of Renown serves to broaden the Company's
  product lines and strengthen its existing customer relationships. &nbsp;In 2004, the
  Company believes the ongoing trend of increased use of metal building products
  will continue because of favorable environmental characteristics, cost
  efficiency and architectural design enhancements</font><b><font size="2">.
  </font> </b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">The Heat Treating segment provides a wide
  array of processes which refine the metallurgical properties of customer-owned
  metal products for a variety of consumer and industrial applications where
  critical performance characteristics are required. This segment services such
  customers as General Motors, Ford, Eaton Corporation, Dana Corporation, and
  International Truck.&nbsp; In 2004, the Company believes the growing trend in the
  outsourcing of heat treating operations will continue and
  that its heat treating facilities are
  strategically located to meet the needs of customers from a geographically
  diverse base of operations. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in">
  <font size="2">The following table sets forth the Company's net sales by reportable segment
  for the period ending December 31:</font></p>
  <table class="MsoTableGrid" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; margin-left: 45.0pt">

      <p class="MsoNormal"><font size="2">$</font></td>
      <td width="112" valign="top" style="width: 83.85pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">

  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b>
  <font size="2">Results of Operations</font></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Year Ended 2003 Compared to Year Ended 2002</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Consolidated</font></i></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Net sales increased by approximately $113.1
  million, or 17.5%, to $758.3 million in 2003, from net sales of $645.1 million
  in 2002.&nbsp; The increase in net sales was primarily due to the addition of net
  sales of B&amp;W Heat Treating (acquired July 1, 2002), Construction Metals
  (acquired April 1, 2003) and Air Vent (acquired May 1, 2003), which
  contributed approximately $87.9 million in additional sales in 2003. The
  remaining increase in net sales is the result of expanded sales penetration
  achieved through the Company's national manufacturing, marketing and
  distribution capabilities, as well as through new product offerings, design
  enhancements on existing product lines and new market opportunities. </font>
  </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Cost of sales increased by approximately $92.3
  million, or 17.8%, to $610.1 million in 2003, from cost of sales of $517.8
  million in 2002. &nbsp;The dollar-for-dollar increase in 2003 cost of sales was
  primarily due to higher sales volume as a result of the B&amp;W Heat Treating,
  Construction Metals and Air Vent acquisitions. Cost of sales as a percentage
  of net sales increased to 80.5% in 2003 from 80.3% in 2002. The slight
  increase in cost of sales as a percentage of net sales in 2003, was the result
  of an increase in raw material, utility, workers compensation and
  transportation costs, as well as increases in fringe benefit costs as a
  percentage of net sales when compared to 2002.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Selling, general
  and administrative expenses increased by approximately $12.2 million, or
  15.8%, to $89.3 million in 2003, from selling, general and administrative
  expenses of $77.1 million in 2002. The dollar-for-dollar increase in 2003
  selling, general and administrative expenses was due primarily to the addition
  of costs from the 2003 acquisitions. Selling, general and administrative
  expenses as a percentage of net sales decreased to 11.8% in 2003 from 12.0% in
  2002.&nbsp; This decrease was primarily due to the impact of the Company's recent
  acquisitions, which have lower selling, general and administrative costs as a
  percentage of net sales than the Company's existing operations. &nbsp;&nbsp;</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Interest expense increased by approximately
  $3.8 million in 2003, primarily due to an increase in debt used to finance the
  2003 acquisitions of Construction Metals and Air Vent, as well as the
  Company's 50% interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC. &nbsp;</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">As a result of the above, income before taxes
  increased by $4.8 million, or 12.1%, to $44.6 million in 2003 from income
  before taxes of $39.8 million in 2002.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Income taxes approximated $17.6 million in
  2003, based on a 39.5% effective rate compared with a 40% effective rate in
  2002.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Segment Information</font></i></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><u>
  <font size="2">Processed Steel Products</font></u><font size="2">
  -Net sales decreased by approximately $4.3 million, or 1.6%, to $268.5
  million in 2003, from net sales of $272.8 million in 2002.&nbsp; This decrease was
  primarily due to decreases in automotive production levels by the &quot;Big Three&quot;
  automotive manufacturers, as well as reduced sales in the service center
  business attributable to the reduction in processed steel demand for use in
  commercial building industry applications.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Income from operations decreased by
  approximately $6.9 million, or 21.1%, to $25.9 million in 2003, compared to
  income from operations of $32.8 million in 2002.&nbsp; Operating margin decreased
  to 9.6% of net sales in 2003 compared to 12.0% in 2002, primarily due to
  higher raw material, transportation, and workers compensation costs as well as
  increases in fringe benefit costs as a percentage of lower net sales.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><u>
  <font size="2">Building Products</font></u><font size="2"> -Net sales increased by approximately $108.3 million, or 37.1%, to
  $400.4 million in 2003, from net sales of $292.2 million in 2002.&nbsp; The
  increase in net sales was due primarily to the addition of net sales of
  Construction Metals (acquired April 1,
  2003) and Air Vent (acquired May 1, 2003), which contributed approximately
  $82.4 million in additional net sales in 2003. The remaining increase in net
  sales was the result of expanded sales penetration through both new and
  redesigned product offerings as well as new market opportunities. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Income from
  operations increased by approximately $18.8 million, or 88.1%, to $40.1
  million in 2003, compared to income from operations of $21.3 million in 2002.&nbsp;
  Operating margin increased to 10.0% of net sales in 2003, compared to 7.3% in
  2002 primarily due to higher income from operations of the 2003 acquisitions,
  and was partially offset by increases in raw material costs during 2003.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><u>
  <font size="2">Heat Treating</font></u><font size="2">
  -Net sales increased by approximately $9.2 million, or 11.5%, to $89.3
  million in 2003 from net sales of $80.2 million in 2002.&nbsp; This increase was
  due primarily to the addition of a full year of net sales of B&amp;W Heat Treating
  (acquired July 1, 2002), which contributed approximately $5.5 million in
  additional net sales in 2003.&nbsp; The remaining increase in net sales was
  primarily the result of increased sales penetration by the Company's new
  brazing operation in Fairfield, Ohio.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Income from operations decreased by
  approximately $.5 million, or 5.2%, to $9.4 million in 2003, compared to
  income from operations of $9.9 million in 2002.&nbsp; Operating margin decreased to
  10.5% of net sales in 2003, compared to 12.4% of net sales in 2002 primarily
  due to higher material, utility and workers compensation costs, as well as
  increases in&nbsp; fringe benefit costs.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Year Ended 2002 Compared to Year Ended 2001</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Consolidated</font></i></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Net sales increased by approximately $29.1
  million, or 4.7%, to $645.1 million in 2002, from net sales of $616.0 million
  in 2001.&nbsp; This increase resulted primarily from increased sales resulting from
  increased production levels in the automotive industry and the July 1, 2002 acquisition of B&amp;W Heat Treating.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Cost of sales increased by approximately $17.9
  million, or 3.5%, to $517.8 million in 2002 from cost of sales of $499.9
  million in 2001.&nbsp; Cost of sales as a percentage of net sales decreased to
  80.3% in 2002 from 81.2% in 2001 primarily due to lower raw material and
  freight costs partially offset by increased direct labor and health care costs
  and general insurance expense. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Selling, general
  and administrative expenses decreased by approximately $1.4 million, or 1.8%,
  to $77.1 million in 2002 from selling, general and administrative expenses of
  $78.6 million in 2001. Selling, general and administrative expenses as a
  percentage of net sales decreased to 12.0% for 2002 from 12.8% for 2001
  primarily due to the elimination of goodwill amortization as a result of the
  implementation of new accounting rules in 2002, partially offset by increased
  incentive compensation.&nbsp; Additionally, in 2001 we had a non-cash charge of
  $1.0 million relating to the Company's E-Commerce investment.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Interest expense decreased by approximately
  $6.0 million in 2002 primarily due to lower average borrowings during 2002 due
  to the use of proceeds from the Company's stock offering in mid-March 2002 and
  lower interest rates. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">As a result of the above, income before taxes
  increased by $18.7 million, or 88%, to $39.8 million in 2002, from income
  before taxes of $21.1 million in 2001.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Income taxes approximated $15.9 million in
  2002, based on a 40% effective rate compared with a 40.5% effective rate in
  2001.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><i>
  <font size="2">Segment Information</font></i></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><u>
  <font size="2">Processed Steel Products</font></u><font size="2">
  -Net sales increased by approximately $20.4 million, or 8.1%, to $272.8
  million in 2002, from net sales of $252.4 million in 2001. &nbsp;This increase was
  due primarily to increased sales resulting from increased production levels in
  the automotive industry in 2002.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Income from operations increased by
  approximately $3.7 million, or 12.6%, to $32.8 million in 2002, compared to
  income from operations of $29.2 million in 2001.&nbsp; Operating margin increased
  to 12.0% of net sales in 2002 compared to 11.6% in 2001, primarily due to
  lower raw material and freight costs, partially offset by increased direct
  labor costs and incentive-based compensation. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><u>
  <font size="2">Building Products</font></u><font size="2"> -Net sales for 2002 of $292.2 million were comparable to net sales of
  $292.4 million for 2001.&nbsp; Weaker demand due to general economic conditions in
  this segment's industry early in the year were offset by an improvement in
  these conditions during the third and fourth quarters, especially through
  sales to major retail outlets.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Income from
  operations increased by approximately $3.2 million, or 17.4%, to $21.3 million
  in 2002, compared to income from operations of $18.2 million in 2001.
  Operating margin increased to 7.3% of net sales in 2002, compared to 6.2% in
  2001 primarily due to lower raw material costs, partially offset by increased
  health care costs, general insurance expense and incentive-based compensation.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid"><u>
  <font size="2">Heat Treating</font></u><font size="2">
  -Net sales increased by approximately $9.0 million, or 12.6%, to $80.2
  million in 2002, from net sales of $71.2 million in 2001.&nbsp; This increase was
  due primarily to the July 1, 2002 acquisition of B&amp;W Heat Treating and
  increased sales resulting from increased production levels in the automotive
  industry.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left:.5in;page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">Income from operations increased by
  approximately $1.1 million, or 12.6%, to $9.9 million in 2002, compared to
  income from operations of $8.8 million in 2001.&nbsp; Operating margin as a
  percentage of net sales of 12.4% for 2002 was comparable to 2001.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><b>
  <font size="2">&nbsp;Critical
  Accounting Policies</font></b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The preparation of
  the financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
  accepted in the United States of America requires management to make decisions
  based upon estimates, assumptions, and factors it considers relevant to the
  circumstances.&nbsp; Such decisions include the selection of applicable principles
  and the use of judgment in their application, the results of which could
  differ from those anticipated.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">A summary of the
  Company's significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 of the
  Company's consolidated financial statements included in Item 8 of this Form
  10-K.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company's most
  critical accounting policies include: valuation of accounts receivable, which
  impacts general and administrative expense; valuation of inventory, which
  impacts cost of sales and gross margin; and the assessment of recoverability
  of goodwill and other intangible and long-lived assets, which impacts
  write-offs of goodwill, intangibles and long-lived assets.&nbsp; Management reviews
  the estimates, including, but not limited to, the allowance for doubtful
  accounts and inventory reserves on a regular basis and makes adjustments based
  on historical experiences, current conditions and future expectations.&nbsp; The
  reviews are performed regularly and adjustments are made as required by
  current available information.&nbsp; Management believes these estimates are
  reasonable, but actual results could differ from these estimates.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company's
  accounts receivable represent those amounts which have been billed to the
  Company's customers but not yet collected.&nbsp; Management analyzes various
  factors including historical experience, credit worthiness of customers and
  current market and economic conditions.&nbsp; The allowance for doubtful accounts
  balance is established based on the portion of those accounts receivable which
  are deemed to be potentially uncollectible.&nbsp; Changes in judgments on these
  factors could impact the timing of costs recognized.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company states
  its inventories at lower of cost or market.&nbsp; The cost basis of the Company's
  inventory is determined on a first-in-first-out basis using either actual
  costs or a standard cost methodology which approximates actual cost.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Intangible assets
  with estimable useful lives (which consist primarily of non-competition
  agreements) are amortized to their residual values over those estimated useful
  lives in proportion to the economic benefit consumed.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Long-lived assets
  with estimated useful lives are depreciated to their residual values over
  those useful lives in proportion to the economic value consumed.&nbsp; Long-lived
  assets are tested for impairment when events or changes in circumstances
  indicate that the carrying amount of a long-lived asset may not be recoverable
  and exceeds its fair market value.&nbsp; This circumstance exists if the carrying
  amount of the asset in question exceeds the sum of the undiscounted cash flows
  expected to result from the use of the asset.&nbsp; The impairment loss would be
  measured as the amount by which the carrying amount of a long-lived asset
  exceeds its fair value as determined by discounted cash flow method or in the
  case of negative cash flow, an independent market appraisal of the asset.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">Goodwill is tested
  annually, or sooner if indicators of impairment exist, for impairment at the
  reporting unit level by comparing the fair value of the reporting unit with
  its carrying value.&nbsp; A reporting unit is either the same as, or one level
  below, an operating segment.&nbsp; The primary valuation method for determining the
  fair value of the reporting unit is a discounted cash flows analysis.&nbsp; If the
  goodwill is indicated as being impaired (the fair value of the reporting unit
  is less than the carrying amount), the fair value of the reporting unit would
  then be allocated to its assets and liabilities in a manner similar to a
  purchase price allocation in order to determine the implied fair value of the
  reporting unit goodwill.&nbsp; This implied fair value of the reporting unit
  goodwill would then be compared with the carrying amount of the reporting unit
  goodwill and, if it is less, the Company would then recognize an impairment
  loss.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The projection of
  future cash flows for the goodwill impairment analysis requires significant
  judgments and estimates with respect to future revenues related to the assets
  and the future cash outlays related to those revenues.&nbsp; Actual revenues and
  related cash flows, changes in anticipated revenues and related cash flows or
  use of different assumptions could result in changes in this assessment.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><b>
  <font size="2">Liquidity and
  Capital Resources</font></b></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">The Company's principal capital requirements
  are to fund its operations, including working capital, the purchase and
  funding of improvements to its facilities, machinery and equipment and to fund
  acquisitions.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2"><br>
  The Company's shareholders' equity increased by
  approximately $101.1 million or 34.5%, to $394.2 million, at December 31,
  2003.&nbsp; This increase was primarily due to the receipt of $70.0 million in net
  proceeds from the Company's common stock offering in December 2003, proceeds
  of $3.6 million from the exercise of stock options, as well as net income of
  $27.0 million, including earnings from the Company's 2003 acquisitions.&nbsp; &nbsp;</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">During 2003, the Company's working capital
  increased $12.5 million, or 9.0%, to approximately $150.7 million.
  The increase in working capital was primarily
  the result of an increase in cash and cash equivalents due to the cash
  proceeds received from the December 2003 common stock offering. The net
  proceeds to the Company from the common stock offering approximated $70.0
  million and approximately $45.0 million was used to pay off the Company's
  LIBOR debt that matured in December 2003. The remaining $25.0 million in cash
  proceeds received from the offering was held in cash and cash equivalents at
  December 31, 2003. Subsequent to year-end, the Company used this $25.0 million
  in cash to pay down the Company's LIBOR debt that matured in January 2004. The
  remaining change in working capital was primarily the result of increases in
  accounts receivable of $16.8 million, offset by increases in the current
  portion of long-term debt of $19.2 million and the aggregate increase in
  accounts payable and accrued expenses of $14.8 million, primarily due to the
  acquisitions of Construction Metals and Air Vent.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">On April 1, 2003, the Company purchased all of
  the outstanding capital stock of Construction Metals and on May 1, 2003, the
  Company purchased all of the outstanding capital stock of Air Vent.&nbsp; The
  Company paid approximately $147 million for both acquisitions, comprised of
  $87.2 million in cash, which included direct acquisition costs, and $59.8
  million in unsecured subordinated debt payable to the former owners of the
  acquired companies over three to five years at annual interest rates ranging
  from 4.0% to 5.0%.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">The Company's primary sources of liquidity are
  cash provided by operating activities and its revolving credit facility.&nbsp; Net
  cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2003 was
  $64.7 million and primarily represents net income plus non-cash charges for
  depreciation and amortization and changes in working capital positions.&nbsp; Net
  cash provided by operating activities in 2003 was due primarily to net income
  of $27.0 million combined with depreciation and amortization of $22.4 million,
  the provision for deferred income taxes of $6.5 million, reductions in
  inventories of $11.1 million and increases in accounts payable and accrued
  expenses of $1.0 million offset by increases in accounts receivable and other
  current assets which aggregated $5.0 million.&nbsp; </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">The $64.7 million of net cash provided by
  operating activities and the net proceeds of $70.0 million from the Company's
  2003 stock offering plus cash on hand at the beginning of the period and cash
  generated by the exercise of stock options of $3.6 million, were used to pay
  down $118.1 million of the Company's long-term debt, to fund current
  operations, the acquisitions of Constructions Metals and Air Vent of $84.2
  million (net of cash acquired), capital expenditures of $22.6 million and pay
  cash dividends of $2.7 million. &nbsp;</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">In April 2003, the Company amended its
  revolving credit facility, which expires in June 2007, to increase the
  aggregate borrowing limit to $290.0 million.&nbsp; Additionally, the revolving
  credit facility contains a $10.0 million expansion feature at the Company's
  option, subject to approval by participating financial institutions.&nbsp;
  Borrowings thereunder are secured with the Company's accounts receivable,
  inventories and personal property and equipment.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003, the
  Company had used approximately $125.0 million of the revolving credit
  facility, resulting in $165.0 million in availability.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003,
  the Company had interest rate swap agreements outstanding which effectively
  converted $50 million of borrowings under its revolving credit agreement to
  fixed interest rates ranging from 7.72% to 8.43%.&nbsp; Additional borrowings under
  the revolving credit facility carry interest at LIBOR plus a fixed rate.&nbsp; At
  December 31, 2003, additional borrowings under the revolving credit facility
  aggregated $75.0 million.&nbsp; The weighted average interest rate of these
  additional borrowings was 3.55% at December 31, 2003.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">The Company's revolving credit facility
  contains various debt covenants.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003 the Company was in
  compliance with all covenants.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">In 2002, the Company entered into a $50 million
  private placement of debt with The Prudential Insurance Company of America,
  which consists of a $25 million senior secured note bearing interest at 7.35%
  annually, due on July 3, 2007 and a $25 million senior subordinated note,
  bearing interest at 8.98% annually, due on January 3, 2008.&nbsp; At December 31,
  2003, the total principal balance of the private placement debt aggregated $50
  million, none of which is due within the next twelve months.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
  </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  &nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; margin-right: .25in; margin-top: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt">
  <font size="2">In January 2004, the underwriters of the
  Company's December 2003 common stock offering exercised a portion of their
  over-allotment option, and purchased an additional 214,625 shares of the
  Company's common stock at $24.75 per share.&nbsp; Net proceeds to the Company from
  the purchase of these additional shares was approximately $5.0 million and was
  &nbsp;used to further reduce the Company's outstanding debt.&nbsp; </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyText" style="line-height: normal; margin-left: .5in">
  <font size="2">The
  Company believes that availability of funds under its credit facility together
  with cash generated from operations will be sufficient to provide the Company
  with the liquidity and capital resources necessary to support its principal
  capital requirements, including operating activities, capital expenditures,
  and dividends. </font> </p>
  <p class="MsoBodyText" style="line-height: normal; margin-left: .5in"><b>

  following table summarizes the Company's contractual obligations at December
  31, 2003:</font></p>
