      <p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height:150%;page-break-after:avoid">
      <font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
      Total</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 77; height: 33; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: 1.0pt solid windowtext; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; line-height: 150%; page-break-after: avoid">
      <font size="2">$&nbsp; 277,781</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 79; height: 33; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: 1.0pt solid windowtext; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; line-height: 150%; page-break-after: avoid">
      <font size="2">$&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 27,591</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 60; height: 33; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: 1.0pt solid windowtext; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align:right;line-height:150%;
  page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">$&nbsp;&nbsp; 42,031</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 62; height: 33; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: 1.0pt solid windowtext; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; line-height: 150%; page-break-after: avoid">
      <font size="2">$&nbsp;&nbsp; 199,887</font></td>
      <td valign="top" style="width: 79; height: 33; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: 1.0pt solid windowtext; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
      <p class="MsoNormal" align="right" style="text-align: right; line-height: 150%; page-break-after: avoid">
      <font size="2">$&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 8,272</font></td>
    </tr>
  </table>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><b>
  &nbsp;Related Party
  Transactions</b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In connection with
  the acquisition of Construction Metals in April 2003, the Company entered into
  two unsecured subordinated notes payable, each in the amount of $8.75 million
  (aggregate total of $17.5 million). These notes are payable to the former
  owners of Construction Metals and are considered related party in nature due
  to the former owners' current employment relationship with the Company.&nbsp; These
  notes are payable in three equal annual principal installments of
  approximately $2.9 million per note, beginning on April 1, 2004, with the
  final principal payment due on April 1, 2006.&nbsp; These notes require quarterly
  interest payments at an interest rate of 5.0% per annum.&nbsp; Interest expense
  related to these notes payable aggregated approximately $660,000 in 2003.&nbsp; At
  December 31, 2003, the current portion of these notes payable aggregated
  approximately $5.8 million and accrued interest aggregated approximately
  $221,000.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company has
  certain operating lease agreements related to operating locations and
  facilities with the former owners of Construction Metals (related parties) or
  companies controlled by these parties.&nbsp; Rental expense associated with these
  related party operating leases aggregated approximately $512,000 in 2003.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><b>
  <font size="2">Recent Accounting Pronouncements</font></b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In June 2001, the
  Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Statement of Financial
  Accounting Standards &nbsp;No. 143, <i>Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations</i>
  (SFAS 143). SFAS 143 requires that the fair value of an asset retirement
  obligation be recognized in the period in which it is incurred.&nbsp; The adoption
  of SFAS 143 did not have a material impact on the Company's results of
  operations.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In June 2002, the
  FASB issued SFAS 146, <i>Accounting for Exit or Disposal Activities.</i> SFAS
  146 requires that a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal
  activity be recognized when the liability is incurred.&nbsp; The provisions of SFAS
  146 are effective for exit or disposal activities that were initiated after
  December 31, 2002 and did not have a material impact on the Company's
  financial position or results of operations.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In November 2002,
  the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No. 45, <i>Guarantor's Accounting and
  Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect Guarantees of
  Indebtedness of Others </i>(FIN 45). FIN 45 requires the fair-value
  measurement and recognition of a liability for the issuance of certain
  guarantees issued or modified on January 1, 2003 or after.&nbsp; Implementation of
  the fair-value measurement and recognition provisions of FIN 45 did not have a
  material impact on the Company's financial position or results of operations.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In December 2002,
  the FASB issued SFAS 148, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation -
  Transition and Disclosure, an Amendment of SFAS No. 123.</i> &nbsp;SFAS 148 amends
  SFAS 123, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</i>, to provide
  alternative methods of transition for a voluntary change to the fair value
  based method of accounting for stock-based employee compensation.&nbsp; In
  addition, SFAS 148 amends the disclosure requirements of SFAS 123 to require
  more prominent and more frequent disclosures in the financial statements
  regarding the effects of stock-based compensation.&nbsp; SFAS 148 is effective for
  financial statements for fiscal years ending after December 15, 2002,
  including certain amendments to required disclosures related to stock-based
  compensation included in condensed financial statements for interim periods
  beginning after December 15, 2002.&nbsp; Adoption of SFAS 148 did not have a
  material impact on the Company's financial position, results of operations or
  cash flows.&nbsp; For further discussion of the Company's stock-based compensation
  arrangements, see Note 1 of the Company's consolidated financial statements
  included in Item 8 herein.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In January 2003,
  the FASB issued FIN 46, <i>Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities.</i>&nbsp;
  This interpretation of Accounting Research Bulletin No. 51, <i>Consolidated
  Financial </i>Statements, addresses consolidation of variable interest
  entities. FIN 46 requires certain variable interest entities to be
  consolidated by the primary beneficiary if the entity does not effectively
  disperse risks among the parties involved. The provisions of FIN 46 are
  effective immediately for those variable interest entities created after
  January 31, 2003.&nbsp; The provisions are effective for financial statements
  issued for the first interim or annual period ending after December 15, 2003
  for those variable interests held prior to February 1, 2003.&nbsp; The adoption of
  this Interpretation did not have any effect on the Company's financial
  position or results of operations.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In April 2003, the
  FASB issued SFAS 149, <i>Amendment of Statement 133 on Derivative Instruments
  and Hedging Activities.</i> SFAS 149 clarifies the accounting for derivatives,
  amending the previously issued SFAS 133, <i>Accounting for Derivative
  Instruments and Hedging Activities.</i>&nbsp; SFAS 149 clarifies under what
  circumstances a contract with an initial net investment meets the
  characteristics of a derivative, amends the definition of any underlying
  contract, and clarifies when a derivative contains a financing components in
  order to increase the comparability of accounting practices under SFAS 133.&nbsp;
  SFAS 149 is effective for contracts entered into or modified after June 30,
  2003.&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS 149 did not have a material impact on the
  Company's consolidated financial statements.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In May 2003, the FASB issued SFAS 150, <i>Accounting for Certain Financial Instruments with
  Characteristics of both Liabilities and Equity</i>. SFAS 150 establishes
  standards for how an issuer classifies and measures certain financial
  instruments with characteristics of both liabilities and equity.&nbsp; SFAS 150
  applies specifically to a number of financial instruments that companies have
  historically presented within their financial statements either as equity or
  between the liabilities section and the equity section, rather than as
  liabilities.&nbsp; SFAS 150 is effective for financial instruments entered into or
  modified after May 31, 2003, and otherwise is effective at the beginning of
  the first interim period beginning after June 15, 2003.&nbsp; Implementation of
  SFAS 150 did not have a material impact on the Company's consolidated
  financial statements.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In December 2003,
  the FASB issued SFAS 132 (revised 2003), <i>Employer's Disclosures About
  Pensions and Other Postretirement Benefits</i>. SFAS 132 (revised 2003),
  revises employers' disclosures about pension plans and other postretirement
  benefit plans. SFAS 132 (revised 2003), does not change the measurement and
  recognition of those plans required by SFAS 87, <i>Employers' Accounting for
  Pensions</i>, SFAS 88, <i>Employers' Accounting for Settlements and
  Curtailments of Defined Benefit Pension Plans and for Termination Benefits</i>,
  and SFAS 106, <i>Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than
  Pensions</i>. SFAS 132 (revised 2003), retains the original disclosure
  requirements of SFAS 132 and requires additional expanded annual and interim
  disclosures to those in the original SFAS 132 about the assets, obligations,
  cash flows, and net periodic benefit costs of defined benefit pension plans
  and other defined benefit postretirement benefit plans. Except for certain
  provisions, the adoption of this Statement is required for financial
  statements with fiscal years ending after December 15, 2003. Implementation of
  SFAS 132 (revised 2003) did not have a material impact on the Company's
  consolidated financial statements. The revised disclosure requirements of this
  Statement are reflected in Notes 8 and 9 of the consolidated financial
  statements included in Item 8 herein.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in"><b><u>
  <font size="2">Item 7A</font></u><font size="2">.
  &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </font> <u><font size="2">Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk</font></u></b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">In the ordinary
  course of business, the Company is exposed to various market risk factors,
  including changes in general economic conditions, competition and raw
  materials pricing and availability.&nbsp; In addition, the Company is exposed to
  market risk, primarily related to its long-term debt.&nbsp; To manage interest rate
  risk, the Company uses both fixed and variable interest rate debt.&nbsp; The
  Company also entered into interest rate swap agreements that converted a
  portion of its &nbsp;variable rate debt to fixed rate debt.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003,
  the Company had $50 million of revolving credit borrowings that was fixed rate
  debt pursuant to these agreements.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The following
  table summarizes the principal cash flows and related interest rates of the
  Company's long-term debt at December 31, 2003 by expected maturity dates.&nbsp; The
  weighted average interest rates are based on the actual rates that existed at
  December 31, 2003.&nbsp; The variable rate debt consists primarily of the credit
  facility, of which $125 million is outstanding at December 31, 2003.&nbsp; A
  hypothetical 1% increase or decrease in interest rates would have changed the
  2003 interest expense by approximately $1.3 million.</font></p>

  The fair value of
  the Company's debt was $249.9 million at December 31, 2003.<br clear="all" style="page-break-before: always">
&nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid"><font size="2">Safe Harbor Statement</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBlockText" style="margin-right:0in; margin-left:0.5in">
  <font size="2">The Company wishes to take
  advantage of the Safe Harbor provisions included in the Private Securities
  Litigation Reform Act of 1995 (the &quot;Act&quot;).&nbsp; Certain information set forth
  herein contains forward-looking statements that are based on current
  expectations, estimates, forecasts and projections about the Company's
  business, and management's beliefs about future operations, results and
  financial position.&nbsp; These statements are not guarantees of future performance
  and involve certain risks, uncertainties and assumptions.&nbsp; Statements by the
  Company, other than historical information, constitute &quot;forward looking
  statements&quot; within the meaning of the Act and may be subject to a number of
  risk factors.&nbsp; Factors that could affect these statements include, but are not
  limited to, the following:&nbsp; the impact of changing steel prices on the
  Company's results of operations; changing demand for the Company's products
  and services; and changes in interest or tax rates.&nbsp; In addition, such
  forward-looking statements could also be effected by general industry and
  market conditions, as well as general economic and political conditions.</font></p>

  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid">&nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid"><b><font size="2">Report of Independent Auditors</font></b></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid">&nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid">&nbsp;</p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">To the Board of
  Directors and<br>
  Shareholders of Gibraltar Steel Corporation</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In our opinion,
  the consolidated financial statements listed in the accompanying index present
  fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Gibraltar Steel
  Corporation and its subsidiaries at December 31, 2003 and 2002, and the
  results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years
  in the period ended December 31, 2003 in conformity with accounting principles
  generally accepted in the United States of America.&nbsp; These financial
  statements are the responsibility of the Company's management; our
  responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on
  our audits.&nbsp; We conducted our audits of these statements in accordance with
  auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of America, which
  require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance
  about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.&nbsp; An
  audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and
  disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles
  used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall
  financial statement presentation.&nbsp; We believe that our audits provide a
  reasonable basis for our opinion.</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid">
  <font size="2">PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP<br>
  Buffalo, New York<br>
  January 30, 2004<br>
&nbsp;</font></p>

        <td valign="top" style="width:8;height:19; padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in">

      </tr>

  </div>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:center;
page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The accompanying notes are
  integral part of these consolidated financial statements</font></p>
  <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:center;
page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</div>
<p>

<font size="2">

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before: always">
&nbsp;</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="center" style="text-align:center;page-break-after:
avoid"><u><font size="2">GIBRALTAR STEEL CORPORATION<br>
NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
<b>1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; SUMMARY
OF SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES</b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u>Principles of
Consolidation</u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The consolidated
financial statements include the accounts of Gibraltar Steel Corporation and
subsidiaries (the Company).&nbsp; All significant intercompany accounts and
transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Use of Estimates</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The preparation of
the consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make
estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the consolidated
financial statements and accompanying notes.&nbsp; Actual results could differ from
those estimates.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Revenue
Recognition</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Revenue is
recognized when products are shipped and the customer takes ownership and
assumes the risk of loss, collection of the relevant receivable is probable,
persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists and the sales price is fixed or
determinable. &nbsp;Sales returns and allowances are treated as reductions to sales
and are provided for based on historical experience and current estimates.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Cash and Cash
Equivalents</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Cash and cash
equivalents include cash on hand, checking accounts and all highly liquid
investments with a maturity of three months or less.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Accounts
Receivable</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Accounts receivable
are recorded at the invoiced amount and do not bear interest. The allowance for
doubtful accounts is the Company's best estimate of the amount of probable
credit losses in the Company's existing accounts receivable. The Company
determines the allowance based on a number of factors, including historical
experience, credit worthiness of customers and current market and economic
conditions. The Company reviews the allowance for doubtful accounts on a regular
basis. Account balances are charged against the allowance after all means of
collection have been exhausted and the potential for recovery is considered
remote. The Company does not have any off-balance sheet exposure related to its
customers.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Accounts receivable
are expected to be collected within one year and are net of the allowance for
doubtful accounts of $2,610,000 and $2,250,000 at December 31, 2003 and 2002,
respectively.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Inventories</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Inventories are
valued at the lower of cost or market.&nbsp; The cost basis of the inventory is
determined on a first-in, first-out basis using either actual costs or a
standard cost methodology which approximates actual cost.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Property, Plant
and Equipment</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Property, plant and
equipment are stated at cost and depreciated over their estimated useful lives
using the straight-line method. Expenditures that extend the useful lives of
assets are capitalized, while repair and maintenance costs are expensed as
incurred. The estimated useful lives of land improvements and buildings and
building improvements is 15 to 40 years, while machinery and equipment is 3 to
20 years.&nbsp; Accelerated methods are used for income tax purposes.&nbsp; Depreciation
expense aggregated $21,644,000, $19,927,000 and $18,976,000 in 2003, 2002 and
2001, respectively.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Interest is
capitalized in connection with construction of qualified assets.&nbsp; Under this
policy, interest of $156,000, $105,000 and $469,000 was capitalized in 2003,
2002 and 2001, respectively. </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Goodwill and
Other Intangible Assets</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Goodwill represents
the excess of costs over fair value of assets of businesses acquired.&nbsp; The
Company adopted the provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
No. 142, <i>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</i> (SFAS 142), as of January
1, 2002.&nbsp; Pursuant to SFAS 142, goodwill and intangible assets acquired in a
purchase business combination and determined to have an indefinite useful life
are not amortized, but instead tested for impairment at least annually in
accordance with the provisions of SFAS 142.&nbsp; SFAS 142 also requires that
intangible assets with estimable useful lives be amortized over their respective
estimated useful lives to their estimated residual values, and reviewed for
impairment in accordance with SFAS 144, <i>Accounting for Impairment or Disposal
of Long-Lived Assets</i>.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Investments in
Partnerships</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The Company's
investments in partnerships are accounted for using the equity method of
accounting, under which the Company's share of the earnings of the partnership
is recognized in income as earned, and distributions are credited against the
investment when received. </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Equity method
goodwill arises when the Company's investment in the partnership exceeds its
applicable share of the fair market value of the partnership's net assets at the
date the partnership was formed. In accordance with SFAS 142, equity method
goodwill is not amortized or tested for impairment in accordance with this
standard. The Company reviews the equity method goodwill in accordance with
Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 18, <i>The Equity Method of Accounting
for Investments in Common Stock</i> (APB Opinion No. 18), under which the
Company would recognize an impairment loss when there is a loss in the value of
the equity method investment which is deemed to be other than a temporary
decline.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Interest Rate
Exchange Agreements</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Interest rate swap
agreements are used by the Company in the management of interest rate risk.&nbsp; The
interest rate swaps are not used for trading purposes and are accounted for as
cash flow hedges under SFAS 133, <i>Accounting for Derivative Instruments and
Hedging Activities</i>. The Company has determined that there is no
ineffectiveness in these hedging relationships based on the criteria set forth
in SFAS 133. The fair value of interest rate swap agreements are recognized as
other non-current liabilities and aggregated $2,387,000 at December 31, 2003.&nbsp;
Gains or losses from changes in the fair value of the swap agreements are
recorded, net of taxes, as components of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Translation of
Foreign Currency</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The assets and
liabilities of the Company's foreign subsidiary are translated into U.S. dollars
at the rate of exchange in effect at the balance sheet date.&nbsp; Income and expense
items are translated at the average exchange rates prevailing during the
period.&nbsp; Gains and losses resulting from foreign currency transactions are
recognized currently in income and those resulting from the translation of
financial statements are accumulated as a separate component of comprehensive
income net of related taxes.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Shareholders'
Equity</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">During 2003 and
2002, the Company declared dividends of $2,962,000 and $2,466,000, respectively,
of which $869,000 and $640,000 are accrued at December 31, 2003 and 2002,
respectively. </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The Company
reacquired 4,000 shares and 15,000 shares of forfeited restricted common stock
in 2003 and 2002, respectively, at a cost of $.01 per share and reduced
additional paid-in capital for an amount equal to the gross unvested portion of
the restricted stock award at the date of forfeiture. These reacquired shares
and related cost are reflected as treasury stock in the consolidated balance
sheets at December 31, 2003 and 2002. &nbsp;</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Comprehensive
Income </font> </u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Comprehensive income
includes net income as well as accumulated other comprehensive loss. The
Company's accumulated other comprehensive loss consists of unrealized gains and
losses on interest rate swaps, minimum pension liability and foreign currency
translation adjustments, which are recorded net of related taxes.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Net Income Per
Share</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Basic net income per
share equals net income divided by the weighted average shares outstanding
during the year.&nbsp; The computation of diluted net income per share includes all
dilutive common stock equivalents in the weighted average shares outstanding. A
reconciliation between basic net income per share and diluted net income per
share for the years ended December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001 is displayed in Note
12.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Income Taxes</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The consolidated
financial statements of the Company have been prepared using the asset and
liability approach in accounting for income taxes which requires the recognition
of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences
of temporary differences between the carrying amounts and the tax bases of other
assets and liabilities.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Fair Market Value
Disclosures</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">SFAS 107, <i>
Disclosures About Fair Market Value of Financial Instruments, </i>defines the
fair value of a financial instrument as the amount at which the instrument could
be exchanged in a current transaction between willing parties.&nbsp; The Company's
cash and cash equivalents are stated at cost which approximates fair value at
December 31, 2003.&nbsp; The fair value of the Company's debt approximated
$249,910,000 at December 31, 2003.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Fair market value
estimates are made at a specific point in time based on relevant market
information about the financial instrument. These estimates are subjective in
nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and,
therefore, cannot be determined with precision. Changes in assumptions could
significantly affect these estimates.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Stock Based
Compensation</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><i><font size="2">Stock options<br>
</font></i><font size="2">In December 2002,
the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued SFAS 148, <i>Accounting
for Stock-Based Compensation-Transition and Disclosure</i> which amends SFAS
123, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</i>.&nbsp; SFAS 148 provides
alternative methods of transition for a voluntary change to the fair value based
method of accounting for stock-based employee compensation and amends the
disclosure requirements of SFAS 123 to require disclosures in both the annual
and interim financial statements about the method of accounting for stock-based
employee compensation and the effect of the method used on reported results.&nbsp; As
allowed by SFAS 123, the Company follows the disclosure requirements of SFAS 123
and SFAS 148, but continues to account for its stock options using the intrinsic
value-based method of accounting as prescribed by APB Opinion No. 25, <i>
Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees</i> (APB Opinion No. 25).&nbsp; Accordingly,
no compensation cost has been recognized for the stock option plans, as stock
options granted under these plans have an exercise price equal to 100% of the
market price of the underlying stock on the date of grant.&nbsp; The Company's stock
option plans are discussed in more detail in Note 13.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The following table
illustrates the pro forma effect on net income and net income per share, had the
Company used the &nbsp;Black-Scholes option pricing model to calculate the fair value
of stock-option based employee compensation pursuant to the provisions of SFAS
123 and SFAS 148 (in thousands, except per share data):</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid">
<font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</font> </p>

    <td width="90" valign="top" style="width: 67.25pt; height: 13.75pt; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid">
<font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

</font> </p>

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid">
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><i><font size="2">Restricted stock
plan<br>
</font></i><font size="2">The Company has a
restricted stock plan for the grant of restricted stock awards to employees and
non-employee directors at a purchase price of $.01 per share. Upon issuance of
the restricted shares, a charge equivalent to the market value of the shares on
the date of grant less the purchase price of $.01 per share is charged to
shareholders' equity (net of applicable tax effects), as unearned compensation
(a contra equity account) and is amortized on a straight-line basis over the
related share restriction period.&nbsp; The Company's restricted stock plan is
discussed in more detail in Note 14. &nbsp;</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Recent
Accounting&nbsp; Pronouncements</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In June 2001, the
FASB issued SFAS 143, <i>Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations</i>. SFAS
143 requires that the fair value of an asset retirement obligation be recognized
in the period in which it is incurred.&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS 143 did not have a
material impact on the Company's results of operations.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In June 2002, the
FASB issued SFAS 146, <i>Accounting for Exit or Disposal Activities.</i> SFAS
146 requires that a liability for a cost associated with an exit or disposal
activity be recognized when the liability is incurred.&nbsp; The provisions of SFAS
146 are effective for exit or disposal activities that were initiated after
December 31, 2002 and did not have a material impact on the Company's financial
position or results of operations.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In November 2002,
the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No. 45, <i>Guarantor's Accounting and
Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect Guarantees of
Indebtedness of Others </i>(FIN 45). FIN 45 requires the fair-value measurement
and recognition of a liability for the issuance of certain guarantees issued or
modified on January 1, 2003 or after.&nbsp; Implementation of the fair-value
measurement and recognition provisions of FIN 45 did not have a material impact
on the Company's financial position or results of operations.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In January 2003, the
FASB issued FIN 46, <i>Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities.</i>&nbsp; This
interpretation of Accounting Research Bulletin No. 51, <i>Consolidated Financial
</i>Statements, addresses consolidation of variable interest entities. FIN 46
requires certain variable interest entities to be consolidated by the primary
beneficiary if the entity does not effectively disperse risks among the parties
involved. The provisions of FIN 46 are effective immediately for those variable
interest entities created after January 31, 2003.&nbsp; The provisions are effective
for financial statements issued for the first interim or annual period ending
after December 15, 2003 for those variable interests held prior to February 1,
2003.&nbsp; The adoption of this Interpretation did not have any effect on the
Company's financial position or results of operations.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In April 2003, the
FASB issued SFAS 149, <i>Amendment of Statement 133 on Derivative Instruments
and Hedging Activities.</i> SFAS 149 clarifies the accounting for derivatives,
amending the previously issued SFAS 133, <i>Accounting for Derivative
Instruments and Hedging Activities.</i>&nbsp; SFAS 149 clarifies under what
circumstances a contract with an initial net investment meets the
characteristics of a derivative amends the definition of any underlying
contract, and clarifies when a derivative contains a financing components in
order to increase the comparability of accounting practices under SFAS 133.&nbsp;
SFAS 149 is effective for contracts entered into or modified after June 30,
2003.&nbsp; The adoption of SFAS 149 did not have a material impact on the Company's
consolidated financial statements.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In May 2003, the
FASB issued SFAS 150, <i>Accounting for Certain Financial Instruments with
Characteristics of both Liabilities and Equity</i>. SFAS 150 establishes
standards for how an issuer classifies and measures certain financial
instruments with characteristics of both liabilities and equity.&nbsp; SFAS 150
applies specifically to a number of financial instruments that companies have
historically presented within their financial statements either as equity or
between the liabilities section and the equity section, rather than as
liabilities.&nbsp; SFAS 150 is effective for financial instruments entered into or
modified after May 31, 2003, and otherwise is effective at the beginning of the
first interim period beginning after June 15, 2003.&nbsp; Implementation of SFAS 150
did not have a material impact on the Company's consolidated financial
statements.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">In December 2003,
the FASB issued SFAS 132 (revised 2003), <i>Employer's Disclosures About
Pensions and Other Postretirement Benefits</i>. SFAS 132 (revised 2003), revises
employers' disclosures about pension plans and other postretirement benefit
plans. SFAS 132 (revised 2003), does not change the measurement and recognition
of those plans required by SFAS 87, <i>Employers' Accounting for Pensions</i>,
SFAS 88, <i>Employers' Accounting for Settlements and Curtailments of Defined
Benefit Pension Plans and for Termination Benefits</i>, and SFAS 106, <i>
Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions</i>. SFAS
132 (revised 2003), retains the original disclosure requirements of SFAS 132 and
requires additional expanded annual and interim disclosures to those in the
original SFAS 132 about the assets, obligations, cash flows, and net periodic
benefit costs of defined benefit pension plans and other defined benefit
postretirement benefit plans. Except for certain provisions, the adoption of
this Statement is required for financial statements with fiscal years ending
after December 15, 2003. Implementation of SFAS 132 (revised 2003) did not have
a material impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements. The
revised disclosure requirements of this Statement are reflected in Notes 8 and
9. </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><u><font size="2">Reclassifications</font></u></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">Certain 2002 amounts
have been reclassified to conform with 2003 presentation.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0in">
<b><font size="2">2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; ACQUISITIONS</font></b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">On February 13,
2001, the Company purchased all of the outstanding capital stock of Pennsylvania
Industrial Heat Treaters, Inc. (PIHT) for approximately $11,000,000, net of cash
acquired.&nbsp; PIHT provides metallurgical heat-treating services and specializes in
heat treating powdered metal parts.&nbsp; The acquisition of PIHT was accounted for
using the purchase method of accounting for business combinations with the
results of PIHT's operations consolidated with the Company's results of
operations from its acquisition date.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">On July 1, 2002, the
Company purchased all of the outstanding capital stock of B&amp;W Heat Treating
(1975) Limited (B&amp;W) for approximately $9,200,000.&nbsp; The purchase price consisted
of approximately $8,500,000 payable in cash and 32,655 shares of the Company's
common stock valued at $700,000, including 12,572 treasury shares.&nbsp; B&amp;W, located
in Ontario, Canada, specializes in commercial heat treating.&nbsp; The results of
operations of B&amp;W have been included in the Company's consolidated financial
statements since the date of acquisition.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">On April 1, 2003,
the Company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Construction Metals, Inc.
(Construction Metals).&nbsp; Construction Metals is headquartered in Ontario,
California and is a manufacturer of a wide array of building and construction
products that are sold to retail and wholesale customers throughout the western
United States.&nbsp; The acquisition of Construction Metals allowed the Company to
eliminate a competitor and strengthen its distribution network in the building
products market.&nbsp; The results of operations of Construction Metals have been
included in the Company's consolidated financial statements since the date of
acquisition.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The aggregate
purchase consideration for the acquisition of Construction Metals was
approximately $29,185,000, which was comprised of approximately $11,685,000 in
cash, including direct acquisition costs, and $17,500,000 of unsecured
subordinated debt, payable to the former owners of Construction Metals.&nbsp; The
purchase price was allocated to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed
based upon respective fair market values.&nbsp; The fair market values of the
property, plant and equipment and identifiable intangible assets were determined
by an independent valuation.&nbsp; The identifiable intangible assets consisted of
non-competition agreements with an aggregate fair market value of approximately
$830,000 (5-year weighted average useful life).&nbsp; The excess consideration over
such fair value was recorded as goodwill and aggregated approximately
$19,201,000, none of which is deductible for tax purposes.&nbsp; The allocation of
purchase consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is as
follows (in thousands):</font></p>
<table class="MsoTableGrid" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; margin-left: 1.25in">

    &nbsp;</td>

  height:13.8pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">830</font></td>
  </tr>
  <tr style="height: 13.8pt">
    <td width="351" valign="top" style="width:262.95pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
  height:13.8pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    <font size="2">Goodwill</font></td>
    <td width="53" valign="top" style="width:39.45pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
  height:13.8pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    &nbsp;</td>
    <td width="73" valign="top" style="width: 55.05pt; height: 13.8pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 1.0pt solid windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">19,201</font></td>
  </tr>
  <tr style="height: 15.05pt">
    <td width="351" valign="top" style="width:262.95pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
  height:15.05pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    &nbsp;</td>
    <td width="53" valign="top" style="width:39.45pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;
  height:15.05pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">$</font></td>
    <td width="73" valign="top" style="width:55.05pt;border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 1.8;
  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;height:15.05pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">29,185</font></td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">As part of the
purchase agreement between the Company and the former owners of Construction
Metals, the Company may be required to pay additional consideration if certain
net sales levels as defined in the purchase agreement are achieved during the
period from acquisition up to March 31, 2006.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">On May 1, 2003, the
Company acquired all of the outstanding stock of Air Vent Inc. (Air Vent).&nbsp; Air
Vent is headquartered in Dallas, Texas and is primarily engaged in the
manufacture and distribution of a complete line of ventilation products and
accessories.&nbsp; The acquisition of Air Vent allowed the Company to eliminate a
competitor and strengthen its position in the building products market.&nbsp; The
results of operations of Air Vent have been included in the Company's
consolidated financial statements since the date of acquisition.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The aggregate
purchase consideration for the acquisition of Air Vent was approximately
$117,798,000, which was comprised of approximately $75,503,000 in cash,
including direct acquisition costs, and $42,295,000 of unsecured subordinated
debt, payable to the former owner of Air Vent.&nbsp; The purchase price was allocated
to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed based upon respective fair market
values. The fair market values of the property, plant and equipment and
identifiable intangible assets were determined by an independent valuation.&nbsp; The
identifiable intangible assets consisted of non-competition agreements with an
aggregate fair market value of approximately $1,400,000 (10-year weighted
average useful life). The excess consideration over such fair value was recorded
as goodwill and aggregated approximately $103,104,000. The allocation of
purchase consideration to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is as
follows (in thousands):</font></p>
<table class="MsoTableGrid" border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse: collapse; margin-left: 1.25in">

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The Company and the
former owner of Air Vent have made a joint election under Internal Revenue Code
(IRC) Section 338(h)(10) which allows the Company to treat the stock purchase as
an asset purchase for tax purposes.&nbsp; As a result of the 338(h)(10) election,
goodwill in the amount of $103,104,000 is expected to be fully deductible for
tax purposes. </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">The following
unaudited pro forma financial information presents the combined results of
operations as if the acquisitions had occurred on January 1, 2002.&nbsp; The pro
forma information includes certain adjustments, including depreciation expense,
interest expense and certain other adjustments, together with related income tax
effects.&nbsp; The pro forma amounts may not be indicative of the results that
actually would have been achieved had the acquisitions occurred as of January 1,
2002 and are not necessarily indicative of future results of the combined
companies (in thousands, except per share date):</font></p>

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; ">
<b>3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; GOODWILL
AND RELATED INTANGIBLE ASSETS</b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; "><i>
Goodwill</i></p>

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
In connection with
the adoption (effective January 1, 2002) of SFAS 142, <i>Goodwill and Intangible
Assets,</i> the Company completed the transitional goodwill impairment
assessment within six months from the date of adoption as allowed by the
standard.&nbsp; Subsequently, goodwill subject to the provisions of SFAS 142 has been
tested for impairment (annual reassessment date as of October 31). The result of
the annual reassessment determined that no goodwill impairments were indicated.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
As described in Note
6, the Company entered into a joint venture with Duferco Farrell Corporation, in
which the Company acquired a 50% partnership interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip
Steel, LLC. The Company's investment in Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC. exceeded
its applicable share of the fair market value of the partnership's net assets at
the date the partnership was formed and resulted in equity method goodwill of
approximately $11,289,000. There was no impairment associated with this equity
method goodwill.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
The impact that the
adoption of SFAS 142 had on net income per share for the years ended December
31, is summarized as follows:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top:0in;margin-right:.25in;margin-bottom:0in;
margin-left:.5in;margin-bottom:.0001pt">&nbsp;</p>

</div>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; "><i>
Intangible Assets</i></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
At December 31, 2003
non-competition agreements related to the 2003 acquisitions are included as part
of the total assets of the Company's Building Products segment.&nbsp; At December 31,
2003, the gross carrying amount and accumulated amortization of these
non-competition agreements aggregated approximately $2,230,000 and $218,000,
respectively.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
Amortization expense
related to these agreements for the year ended December 31, 2003 and 2002
aggregated approximately $218,000 and $0, respectively.&nbsp; Amortization expense
related these agreements for the next five years is as follows:&nbsp; 2004 -
$306,000; 2005 -$306,000; 2006 -$306,000; 2007 -$306,000; and 2008 -
$182,000.</p>

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; ">
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; ">
<b>6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
INVESTMENTS IN PARTNERSHIPS</b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
The Company has a
31% partnership interest in a steel pickling joint venture with Samuel
Manu-Tech, Inc.&nbsp; The partnership provides a steel cleaning process called
pickling to steel mills and steel processors. The investment is accounted for
using the equity method of accounting. &nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's investment in the
partnership was approximately $3,454,000 and $3,852,000 at December 31, 2003 and
2002, respectively.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
In December 2003,
the Company entered into a joint venture with Duferco Farrell Corporation, in
which the Company acquired a 50% partnership interest in Gibraltar DFC Strip
Steel, LLC. The joint venture was formed for the purpose of manufacturing and
distributing cold-rolled strip steel products.&nbsp; The investment is accounted for
using the equity method of accounting.&nbsp; The Company's investment in the joint
venture was approximately $1,590,000 at December 31, 2003.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; ">
<b>7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; DEBT&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
Long-term debt at
December 31 consists of the following:</p>

  padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">

  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">166,308</font></td>
  </tr>

<p class="MsoNormal">
<br>
The Company's revolving credit facility of $290,000,000 is collateralized by the
Company's accounts receivable, inventories, and
personal property and equipment ,
and is committed through June 2007 and contains a $10,000,000 expansion feature
at the Company's option, subject to approval by the participating financial
institutions.&nbsp; This facility has various interest rate options, which are no
greater than the bank's prime rate.&nbsp; In addition, the Company may enter into
interest rate exchange agreements (swaps) to manage interest costs and exposure
to changing interest rates.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003, the Company had interest rate
swap agreements outstanding which expire starting in 2004 and effectively
converted $50,000,000 of floating rate debt to fixed rates ranging from 7.72% to
8.43%.&nbsp; Additional borrowings under the revolving credit facility aggregated
$75,000,000 and $62,470,000 with an interest rate of LIBOR plus a fixed rate at
December 31, 2003 and 2002, respectively.&nbsp; &nbsp;The weighted average interest rate
of these additional borrowings was 3.55% and 3.23% at December 31, 2003 and
2002, respectively.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
The Company's acquisition notes payable consists of debt incurred in connection
with the 2003 acquisitions of Construction Metals and Air Vent.&nbsp; In connection
with the acquisition of Construction Metals, the Company entered into two
unsecured subordinated notes payable each in the amount of $8,750,000 (aggregate
total of $17,500,000). These notes are payable to the two former owners of
Construction Metals and are considered related party in nature due to the former
owners' current employment relationship with the Company.&nbsp; These notes are
payable in three equal annual principal installments of $2,917,000 per note,
beginning on April 1, 2004, with the final principal payment due on April 1,
2006.&nbsp; These notes require quarterly interest payments at an interest rate of
5.0% per annum.&nbsp; Interest expense related to these notes payable aggregated
approximately $660,000 in 2003.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003, the current portion of
these notes aggregated approximately $5,834,000 and accrued interest aggregated
approximately $221,000.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
In connection with the acquisition of Air Vent, the Company entered into an
unsecured subordinated note payable to the former owner of Air Vent, in the
amount of $42,295,000.&nbsp; The note is payable in five annual principal
installments of $8,459,000 beginning on May 1, 2004, with the final principal
payment due on May 1, 2008. The unpaid principal balance of $40,000,000 accrues
interest at a rate of 5.0% per annum and $2,295,000 of the unpaid principal
balance accrues interest at a rate of 4.0% per annum.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
The Company's private placement demand notes consist of a $25,000,000 senior
secured note bearing interest at 7.35% annually, due on July 3, 2007 and a
$25,000,000 senior subordinated note bearing interest at 8.98% annually, due on
January 3, 2008.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
In addition, the Company has Industrial Development Revenue Bonds payable in
installments through September 2018, with interest rates ranging from a fixed
rate of 4.22% to variable rates of up to 2.90% at December 31, 2003, which
financed the cost of the expansion of its Coldwater, Michigan heat-treating
facility under a capital lease agreement.&nbsp; The cost of the facility and
equipment equals the amount of the bonds and includes accumulated amortization
of $678,000.&nbsp; The agreement provides for the purchase of the facility and
equipment at any time during the lease term at scheduled amounts or at the end
of the lease for a nominal amount.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
In connection with the Company's purchase of a 50% partnership interest in
Gibraltar DFC Strip Steel, LLC, the Company entered into a short-term note
payable to Duferco Farrell Corporation in the amount of $5,000,000.&nbsp; The note
bears no interest and is payable in ten monthly installments of $500,000
beginning in January 2004.&nbsp; </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent">The aggregate maturities on long-term debt for the
next five years and thereafter are as follows:&nbsp; 2004 -$19,848,000; 2005 -
$14,692,000; 2006 -$14,492,000; 2007 -$158,659,000; 2008 -$33,559,000; and
$1,000,000, thereafter.&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
The various loan agreements, which do not require compensating balances, contain
provisions that limit additional borrowings and require maintenance of minimum
net worth and financial ratios. The Company is in compliance with the terms and
provisions of all its financing agreements.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
Total cash paid for interest in the years ended December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001
was $12,632,000,&nbsp; $10,050,000 and $17,122,000, respectively.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; ">
<b>8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; EMPLOYEE
RETIREMENT PLANS</b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
Certain subsidiaries participate in the Company's 40l(k) Plan.&nbsp; In addition,
certain subsidiaries have multi-employer non-contributory retirement plans
providing for defined contributions to union retirement funds.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
The Company has a supplemental pension plan which provides defined pension
benefits to certain salaried employees upon retirement.&nbsp; Benefits under the plan
are based on the salaries of individual plan participants.&nbsp; The Company is
accruing for these benefit payments based upon an independent actuarial
calculation.&nbsp; The following table presents the changes in the plan's projected
benefit obligation, fair value of plan assets and funded status for the years
ended December 31:</p>

    &nbsp;</td>

    <font size="2">Amounts recognized in the consolidated</font></td>

    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" style="width:67;padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>

    <font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Accumulated other comprehensive loss-<br>

    <p class="MsoTitle" align="right" style="text-align:right;page-break-after:avoid">
    &nbsp;</p>

    <p class="MsoTitle" align="right" style="text-align:right;page-break-after:avoid">

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; ">
The plan's accumulated benefit obligation was
$1,791,000, $1,652,000 and $1,269,000 at December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001,
respectively. </p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; ">
The measurement date used to determine pension
benefit measures is December 31.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; ">
Components of net periodic pension cost for the
years ended December 31 are as follows:</p>

    &nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" style="width:308;height:15.8pt; padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in">
    <p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style="text-align: center"><u>
    <font size="2">(in thousands)</font></u></td>
  </tr>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; ">
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
Employer contributions to the plan for 2004 are expected to be $25,000.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
Total expense for
all retirement plans was $3,130,000, $2,709,000 and $2,200,000 for the years
ended December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; ">
<b>9.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; OTHER
POSTRETIREMENT BENEFITS</b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
Certain subsidiaries
of the Company provide health and life insurance to substantially all of their
employees and to a number of retirees and their spouses. </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; ">
The following table
presents the changes in the accumulated postretirement benefit obligation
related to the Company's postretirement healthcare benefits at December 31:</p>

    <font size="2">(1,869)</font></td>
    <td valign="top" style="width:41;padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</p>
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">$</font></td>
    <td valign="top" style="width: 50; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 2.0pt double windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</p>
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">(1,609)</font></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td width="255" valign="top" style="margin-left:0; margin-right:0; padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in" nowrap>
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    &nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" style="width:26;padding-left:5.4pt; padding-right:5.4pt; padding-top:0in; padding-bottom:0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td valign="top" style="width: 56; border: medium none; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>

<p class="MsoNormal">
Components of net periodic postretirement benefit cost charged to expense for
the years ended December 31 are as follows:</p>

    <td width="312" valign="top" style="width:3.25in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt" nowrap>
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    <font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Expected return on plan assets</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">-</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoTitle" align="right" style="text-align:right;page-break-after:avoid">
    <font size="2">-</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">-</font></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td width="312" valign="top" style="width:3.25in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt" nowrap>
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    <font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Rate of compensation increase</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">-</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoTitle" align="right" style="text-align:right;page-break-after:avoid">
    <font size="2">-</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">-</font></td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
The medical
inflation rate was assumed to be 8.0% in 2003, decreasing gradually to 5.0% in
2006.&nbsp; The effect of a 1% increase or decrease in the annual medical inflation
rate would increase or decrease the accumulated postretirement benefit
obligation at December 31, 2003, by approximately $544,000 and $471,000,
respectively and increase or decrease the annual service and interest costs by
approximately $51,000 and $43,000, respectively.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
The measurement date
used to determine postretirement benefit obligation measures is December 31.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
One of the Company's
subsidiaries also provides postretirement healthcare benefits to its unionized
employees through contributions to a multi-employer healthcare plan.</p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
<b>10.&nbsp; INCOME TAXES</b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
The provision for
income taxes for the years ending December 31 consisted of the following:</p>

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">The provision for
income taxes differs from the federal statutory rate of 35% due to the
following:</font></p>

    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left:0in;page-break-after:avoid">
    <font size="2">Goodwill</font></td>
    <td width="55" valign="top" style="width:41.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid">&nbsp;</td>
    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width:48.6pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">

    <td width="65" valign="top" style="width: 48.6pt; border-left: medium none; border-right: medium none; border-top: medium none; border-bottom: 1.0pt solid windowtext; padding-left: 5.4pt; padding-right: 5.4pt; padding-top: 0in; padding-bottom: 0in">
    <p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" align="right" style="margin-left:0in;text-align:
  right;page-break-after:avoid"><font size="2">(8,374)</font></td>
  </tr>
  <tr>
    <td width="432" valign="top" style="width:4.5in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt">

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">Cash paid for income
taxes, net of tax refunds, in the years ended December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001
was $12,823,000, $7,320,000 And $3,570,000, respectively.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
<b><font size="2">11.&nbsp; </font> </b><font size="2">&nbsp;</font><b><font size="2">COMMON
STOCK</font></b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">In December 2003,
the Company completed an offering of 3,000,000 shares of common stock at a price
of $24.75 per share.&nbsp; Net proceeds to the Company aggregated approximately
$70,000,000.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 0.5in">
<b><font size="2">12.&nbsp; NET INCOME
PER SHARE</font></b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">

per share on the face of the income statement.&nbsp; The reconciliation between the
computations is as follows:</font></p>

  </tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">Basic net income per
share equals net income divided by the weighted average shares outstanding for
the years ended December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.&nbsp; The computation
of diluted net income per share includes all dilutive common stock equivalents
in the weighted average shares outstanding.&nbsp; The treasury stock method is used
to calculate dilutive shares which reduces the gross number of dilutive shares
by the number of shares purchasable from the assumed proceeds of common stock
equivalents.&nbsp; Included in diluted shares are common stock equivalents relating
to stock options and restricted stock awards of 163,092, 238,662 and 182,183 for
the years ended December 31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
<b><font size="2">13.&nbsp; STOCK OPTION
PLANS</font></b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">The Company has a
non-qualified stock option plan, whereby the Company may grant non-qualified
stock options to officers, employees, non-employee directors and advisers.&nbsp;
Under the non-qualified stock option plan, 400,000 shares of common stock were
reserved for the granting of options.&nbsp; Options are granted under this plan at an
exercise price not less than the fair market value of the shares at the date of
grant.&nbsp; These options vest ratably over a four-year period from the grant date
and expire ten years after the date of grant.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003, 152,500
shares remain available for issuance under the non-qualified stock option plan.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">In 1993, the Company
adopted an incentive stock option plan, whereby the Company may grant incentive
stock options to officers and other key employees.&nbsp; Under this plan, 1,625,000
shares of common stock were reserved for the granting of stock options at an
exercise price not less than the fair market value of the shares at the date of
grant. Options granted under this plan vest ratably over a four-year period from
the grant date and expire ten years after the date of grant.&nbsp; In September 2003,
this plan expired. The expiration of this plan did not modify, amend or
otherwise affect the terms of any outstanding options on the date of the plan's
expiration.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">In 2003, the
Company's Board of Directors approved the adoption of a new incentive stock
option plan, whereby the Company may grant incentive stock options to officers
and other key employees. Under this plan, 1,500,000 shares of common stock were
reserved for the granting of stock options. These options are granted at an
exercise price not less than the fair market value of the shares at the date of
grant. Options granted under this plan vest ratably over a four-year period from
the grant date and expire ten years after the date of grant. As of December 31,
2003, this plan had not yet been approved by the Company's shareholders, and
1,500,000 shares remain available for issuance under this plan.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">The following table
summaries the ranges of outstanding and exercisable options at December 31,
2003:</font></p>

<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">At December 31,
2003, all exercisable options had an exercise price below the $25.17 per share
market price of the Company's common stock.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">Tax benefits of
$949,000, $349,000 and $40,000 realized in the years ended December 31, 2003,
2002 and 2001, respectively, associated with the exercise of certain stock
options have been credited to additional paid-in-capital.&nbsp; </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
<b><font size="2">14.&nbsp; </font> </b><font size="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><b><font size="2">RESTRICTED
STOCK PLAN</font></b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">The Company has a
restricted stock plan and has reserved for issuance 250,000 common shares for
the grant of restricted stock awards to employees and non-employee directors at
a purchase price of $.01 per share.&nbsp; Shares of restricted stock issued under
this plan vest on a straight-line basis over a period of 5 to 10 years. The
Company recognized compensation expense associated with the lapse of
restrictions in the amounts of $282,000, $287,000 and $117,000, during 2003,
2002 and 2001, respectively.&nbsp; At December 31, 2003, 135,000 shares remain
available for issuance under the restricted stock plan.&nbsp; </font> </p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.25in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: .75in">
<b><font size="2">15.&nbsp; SEGMENT
INFORMATION</font></b></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">The Company is
organized into three reportable segments on the basis of the production process
and products and services provided by each segment, identified as follows:</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.5in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 1.5in">
<font size="2">(i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Processed steel products, which primarily includes the intermediate processing
of wide, open tolerance flat-rolled sheet steel through the application of
several different processes to produce high-quality, value-added coiled steel
products to be further processed by customers.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.5in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 1.5in">
<font size="2">(ii)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Building products, which primarily includes the processing of sheet steel to
produce a wide variety of building and construction products.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-indent: -.5in; page-break-after: avoid; margin-left: 1.5in">
<font size="2">(iii)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
Heat treating, which includes a wide range of metallurgical heat-treating
processes in which customer-owned metal parts are exposed to precise
temperatures, atmospheres and quenchants to improve their mechanical properties,
durability and wear resistance.</font></p>
<p class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="page-break-after:avoid; margin-left:0.5in">
<font size="2">The following table
illustrates certain measurements used by management to assess the performance of
the segments described above as of and for the years ended December 31, 2003,
2002 and 2001:</font></p>
